comment: All of the quizzes and tests were open note, as long as you had your textbook open you can pass this class. It seemed like HW was graded based on answering the questions more than getting them right. I wouldn't stress about this class at all I passed and didn't complete the last HW assignment.

He randomly changes grading rules and delays feedback, causing repeated bad grades for one mistake. His industry expectations are unrealistic & he recycles CS courses for IT without creating his own. He brags about exp but gives contradictory instructions that make no sense. His approach is disorganized, leaving students frustrated & unprepared.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Privitera lacks enthusiasm for teaching and does little to support students. If you face a personal emergency, he suggests withdrawing instead of offering help. His communication is poor, and he seems uninterested in student success. KSU should consider a replacement who is more supportive and engaged in student learning.

This professor is absolutely horrible to deal with. Grades are extremely unpredictable and do not reward great work. Professor is also very condescending and will evaporate every last piece of motivation you have to contribute to this course.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: If you plan on taking a capstone class with the professor, make sure you're prepared to put in the work. The professor has clear information on what he expects in the milestone and final preparations materials so, make sure you gather together a team as early as possible and you should do fine. This is a difficult class so, attend the Q&A sessions!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--So many papers

comment: Professor Privitera is a professor that will hold you rightfully accountable throughout the semester. I enjoy the fact that this professor is invested in their work. We need professors who are invested in the curriculum and student success so I would recommend Privitera if you take your work and education seriously as well. Just put in effort.

I had the privilege of taking a class with Professor Privitera, and I can say with confidence that he is an outstanding educator who genuinely cares about his students' success. The tests in the class were aligned with what we learned in class. The hybrid format of the class was well-structured.

Prof. Privitera is passionate about the coursework and students success in his class. He went the extra mile to help my team overcome a particularly unfortunate scenario, that we found ourselves in. He took time on his weekends to meet with us, help guide us onto a better path, and with great feedback, finish the project successfully.

This class is a great refresher for those who have used Python before. He is very understanding, and if you email him, he will work with you to help you pass his class! If it wasn't my last semester, I'd love to take another class with him.

Dr. Privitera was one of the most interesting professors I have ever had. While going through the Capstone, he was always available for questions when we need him and always pushed us to look further into the work. Make sure you are prepared for your Capstone, but as long as you are willing to put in the time and effort, he will help you succeed.

Capstone Projects are hard so the class was difficult, but Professor Privitera was almost always available via Microsoft Teams or by email to help with anything that the team with the Capstone Project. He also had clear expectations on what he wanted turned in and when he wanted it turned in. This made it easy to focus and learn as much as possible
Professor Privitera is a helpful professor. He was my capstone project grader. He has clear grading criteria and is a fair grader.

Professor Privitera was .... interesting. He expects perfection and can be very harsh. He's almost pretty slow to respond to emails. I'd go with another professor if you could, but if you can't, prioritize getting a project that motivates you to meet his demands.

I had no issues with the professor, though there was a bit of a rocky start during project assignment. Some people missed out on projects they wanted to sign up for, as things were a bit disorganized. Tip for future capstone students: Set up D2L notifications so they go to your phone so you don't miss important announcements. Good luck!

Overall great Professor. He was very helpful and his lectures was a pleasure to listen to. He was nice and engaged with students, asking questions and throwing in his own personal experiences and knowledge to further hammer down the point, which helped keep me engaged in lecture. He used a free online textbook that was well written and convenient.
Outside of school hes a nice guy but in class he can be a serious pain in the behind. He expects to experts in an introductory programming course.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Get ready to read

comment: I really enjoyed the professor and the class subject. I learned about tools and topics that I can apply to my actual career, which can be rare. I thought the professor provided helpful videos and and links that allowed us to fully understand the subjects. Anytime that I had questions, he was very responsive. I highly recommend him.
I had a great experience. Some of the course material was dated and he found more recent/relevant info. Even had a former colleague speak with us about current security issues. 10/10
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: I learned so much this class. The feedback that I received on each assignment truly made a difference in my understanding of the material. He was lenient in his grading and tried to help where he could. I feel that if the concepts were met, he did not nitpick when it came to grading. Overall, very enjoyable class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: The labs (Wireshark) requires a lot of analysis- they start off easy but ramp up in complexity, especially with the final lab. He does not accept late work but may offer extra credit at the end of the semester depending on overall class performance. Simple weekly discussions. He provides ppts/helpful links and has a study checklist for the final.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: This professor did not seem to care much at all for the duration of this semester. He seemed to use course material that was taken from other professors and just hoped that a simple copy/paste would get him by. This left the entire class utterly confused most of the semester. From his snarky comments to late grade returns, Id reconsider taking him

Harps on citations but uses random links for content. Very disrespectful to students, regardless of background. Rearranged my schedule because I realized I had him for another class (yes he's that bad). Do not register with him for a class if you value your education or want anything that resembles clear instruction. If you take him, good luck.

So I normally am okay with hard teachers but this teacher right here constantly was changing things up till the due date and would penalize you for things that arent even in the rubric. Utter failure of a teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Test heavy

comment: All quizzes (6 total) are lockdown browser with webcam. In order to understand the material, you have to read 20 - 30 links provided for each module. Final is also lockdown browser with webcam. Mandatory citations and references in discussion posts. Final team project was a 10 page paper that had not much to do with the class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Harder than need be. He wasnt familiar with the course. The final group project was 10 pages and instructions were so unclear that I think every student had a different interpretation of what was said. Discussions were too deep for 2% per post. take notes on the slides to pass quizzes. Lockdown on everything. Too many links to read
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Tough grader

comment: He did not look at the course material at all. He did not know the scope of the work that was asked for and constantly sent passive aggressive announcements out that insulted our intelligence as a class. He harps on citations but barely skims the content if he reads it at all. If you have the time to keep up with the constant changes then easy A

Privitera seemed to deliberately make the class more difficult than it needed to be. There is supposed to be a paper or wireshark option for the final project. He only gave us the wireshark option which is much more difficult. He is a tough grader. He does not go over content relevant to the assignments or labs making the class feel unprepared
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Tough grader

comment: Work due every 2 weeks: Reading lots of links/textbook sections, Assignment, discussion post, and quiz. Makes you do quizzes with lockdown browser+webcam, averages quizzes instead of best attempt. 7-10 page group project -1 page proposals for every group member (said they don't count in the 7-10 pages 2 days before it was due).

Probably the most inept professor in the IT department. He's like an old school professor but with little teaching experience and his technical knowledge is mediocre at best. The fact the he received his masters from KSU makes me question my academic choice. His syllabus and quizzes are inundated with grammatical errors. I would avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Prof Privitera is passionate about DataComm and responds promptly to emails. Book is free online and interesting; you'll read 2-3 chapters/week. 8 quizzes (not weekly) that can cover 1-5 chapters each. Assignments aren't bad, but labs require time and effort. Follow lab format EXACTLY! Open-book midterm and final. Just expect to do 4000-level work.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Get ready to read
